docs.lead_paragraph: For years, women -- particularly those whose husbands earn a healthy income -- have felt they had to choose between an all-consuming job and staying at home to raise their children. But the evidence now suggests that more and more women are finding a middle way that rejects both extremes. Distrustful of dawn-to-dusk child care and unable to negotiate flexible work schedules, a growing number of women are conducting their lives in chapters, devoting their adulthood largely to careers but taking time off to be full-time mothers while their children are young.

headline.main: Job Track or 'Mommy Track'? Some Do Both, in Phases

docs.abstract: Interviews and surveys show women from 25 to 45 years of age are now more likely than they were in past to describe staying at home with their children as phase in life that gives equal importance to paid employment; that is particularly true of college-educated mothers, whose numbers in paid employment keep rising, even as many of them spend more time at home before their children are ready for schooling; studies also show that time spent at work is climbing fastest among women with high-earning husbands; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The subway is a place of extremes. In a crowded city, it is more crowded. In a noisy city, it is deafening. In a smelly city, it is the source from which the original ferment seems to rise. So yesterday, as the first heat wave of summer closed its firm and sweaty grip on the city, the subway was the place where the suffering was truly sublime, where people wore dishrags as hats and hand towels as neckties. It was where pregnant women collapsed and tourists looked stricken, where people took Poland Spring showers and platform conductors jumped into air-conditioned cars solely for the 10 seconds of cool air they could steal before the train doors closed again.

headline.main: When City's an Oven, the Subway's a Broiler

docs.abstract: Heat wave punishing New York is even fiercer on subway platforms; photos; map of temperature readings recorded on drive through Manhattan shows that it can be a lot harder on street than in leafy Central Park, where official reading tops out at 95 degrees (M)
